claim: Major studies conclude that nuclear power is a safe source of energy and there is no scientific consensus that it is less safe than other sources of energy.

supporting.text: Nuclear power plants have lower accident-related fatalities per unit of energy produced compared to fossil fuel plants, based on historical data.

attacks.text: Nuclear power plants have lower accident-related fatalities per unit of energy produced compared to fossil fuel plants, based on historical data.
Historical data excludes long-term health impacts of radiation exposure from nuclear accidents, which may significantly increase fatalities over time.
Modern nuclear plants have enhanced safety measures that minimize radiation leaks, reducing long-term health risks compared to older designs.
Fossil fuel plants cause deaths primarily through air pollution, which is a chronic and widespread issue, whereas nuclear accidents are rare but catastrophic.
The rarity of nuclear accidents means their statistical impact on fatality rates remains low even when accounting for potential catastrophes.

supporting.text: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) reports that nuclear power has one of the lowest rates of direct health impacts among major energy sources.

attacks.text: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) reports that nuclear power has one of the lowest rates of direct health impacts among major energy sources.
The IAEA's report does not account for long-term health impacts of nuclear waste storage and potential accidents.
Studies on nuclear waste storage show that modern containment methods effectively minimize long-term health risks.
Historical nuclear accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima demonstrate catastrophic health impacts that are not reflected in typical IAEA statistics.
Modern nuclear reactor designs incorporate passive safety features that make accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima physically impossible.

supporting.text: Modern nuclear reactor designs incorporate multiple safety features that significantly reduce the risk of catastrophic failure.

attacks.text: Modern nuclear reactor designs incorporate multiple safety features that significantly reduce the risk of catastrophic failure.
Even with modern designs, human error and natural disasters can still lead to catastrophic failures, as seen in Fukushima.
Fukushima was an older reactor design, and modern reactors have passive safety systems that do not rely on human intervention.
The long-term storage of nuclear waste remains an unsolved problem, posing significant safety risks.
Advanced reprocessing technologies and next-gen reactors can reduce nuclear waste and its associated risks.
The high cost and long construction times of modern nuclear reactors make them less practical compared to renewable energy sources.
Nuclear energy provides stable baseload power, unlike intermittent renewables, justifying its higher initial costs.

supporting.text: Studies by the World Health Organization (WHO) indicate that radiation exposure from properly managed nuclear plants is minimal and poses no significant health risk.

attacks.text: Studies by the World Health Organization (WHO) indicate that radiation exposure from properly managed nuclear plants is minimal and poses no significant health risk.
The WHO studies focus on ideal conditions, but accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima show catastrophic risks when management fails.
Modern nuclear plants have advanced safety features that make Chernobyl-style accidents physically impossible.
Long-term storage of nuclear waste remains an unsolved problem, creating potential future radiation hazards.
New reactor designs can consume nuclear waste as fuel, drastically reducing storage needs.

supporting.text: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) recognizes nuclear energy as a low-carbon energy source with safety records comparable to renewables.

attacks.text: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) recognizes nuclear energy as a low-carbon energy source with safety records comparable to renewables.
The IPCC's assessment does not account for rare but catastrophic nuclear accidents like Chernobyl or Fukushima, which have long-term environmental and health impacts.
Modern nuclear reactor designs (e.g., Gen III+/IV) incorporate passive safety features that make Chernobyl/Fukushima-type accidents physically impossible.
Nuclear waste storage remains an unresolved safety issue, with no operational long-term repositories globally after decades of research.
Advanced reprocessing technologies (e.g., fast reactors) can reduce nuclear waste volume by 90% and utilize it as fuel.
The IPCC's comparison with renewables excludes indirect safety risks like uranium mining and nuclear proliferation.

supporting.text: Statistical analyses show that nuclear energy causes fewer deaths per terawatt-hour than coal, oil, and natural gas.

attacks.text: Statistical analyses show that nuclear energy causes fewer deaths per terawatt-hour than coal, oil, and natural gas.
The statistical analyses often exclude long-term deaths from nuclear waste storage and potential accidents like Chernobyl or Fukushima.
Studies on Chernobyl and Fukushima show that long-term death tolls are still lower than annual deaths from fossil fuel pollution.
Nuclear energy's safety depends on strict regulatory oversight, which is not guaranteed in all countries.
International agencies like the IAEA enforce safety standards globally, reducing the risk of regulatory failure.
The comparison ignores deaths from uranium mining and enrichment, which are part of the nuclear fuel cycle.
Modern uranium mining practices and alternative fuel cycles (e.g., thorium) significantly reduce these risks.
